comments:
INSR205 describes how corporations, non-profit organizations, and other organizations manage pure risks. The costs associated with such pure risks as product liability, environmental impairments, property losses, work-related injuries, and employee benefits affect the daily management of organizations. The course examines a common set of techniques which can be used by managers in dealing with these problems, including risk assumption, prevention, diversification, and transfer via insurance and non-insurance market mechanisms. In turn, students learn to recognize that the institutional structure of the organization itself influence its own risks and their corresponding treatments.

Students found the class at times to be “very boring,” claiming that there was not a lot of discussion involved. Students had mixed feelings about the effectiveness of Harrington’s lecture style.

Some students felt Harrington was “too arrogant” and got side tracked easily, making classes hard to follow. One student said the Harrington “assumes you have outside information” and makes it difficult to keep up.

Overall, the students found the workload to be light and easy with the exception of the third module which most students found difficult. This subject is not recommended for non-majors and only slightly recommended for majors.
